title: 105_hr344
content: A Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare is established to fulfill specific duties. The Commission will assess spending patterns in the Medicare program, the long-term solvency of the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, and the feasibility of expanding choices for beneficiaries. They will also examine how waste, fraud, and abuse may impact the trust funds' solvency. The Commission will evaluate the Medicare program for issues like waste, fraud, and abuse, as well as the quality of services and effectiveness of its structure. They will provide specific recommendations to Congress based on their findings. SEC. 3. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate majority leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives, with specific criteria for party affiliation and age. The Commission, consisting of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate majority leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives, must have a diverse political party representation and include at least one member under 35 years old. The members must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment, elect a chairman at their first meeting, fill vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment, and require a quorum of 8 members for decision-making. The Commission, with 15 members appointed by various officials, must have diverse political party representation and include a member under 35 years old. A quorum of 8 members is required for decision-making. Members are not compensated but may be reimbursed for expenses. SEC. 4. STAFF AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission may appoint staff and consultants as necessary without following certain regulations. SEC. 5. POWERS. The Commission may hold hearings, conduct studies, and request cost estimates from the Congressional Budget Office to carry out its duties. The Commission shall reimburse the Director of the Congressional Budget Office for related expenses. The Commission may request additional staff from Federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties. Federal agencies are authorized to detail personnel to the Commission without affecting their civil service status. The Commission can also request technical assistance and use the United States mails like Federal agencies. The Commission, like Federal agencies, can obtain necessary information, receive administrative support services from the General Services Administrator, and accept donations of services or property. The Commission can accept donations of services or property and is considered a committee of Congress for printing and binding costs. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment, including findings, recommendations, and suggestions for legislative action. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report.
